item.title: [Create] Reconnecting After Estrangement: A Journey…
item.content:encoded: {"@context":["https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams",{"Hashtag":"as:Hashtag","sensitive":"as:sensitive","dcterms":"http://purl.org/dc/terms/"}],"id":"https://patlineberry.com/?post_type=ap_outbox\u0026p=1650","type":"Create","published":"2025-07-16T16:57:56Z","to":["https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"],"cc":["https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/actors/0/followers"],"object":{"id":"https://patlineberry.com/?p=1642","type":"Note","attachment":[{"type":"Image","url":"https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/image-1.png?w=1024","mediaType":"image/png"}],"attributedTo":"https://patlineberry.com/?author=0","content":"\u003Ch2\u003EReconnecting After Estrangement: A Journey of Patience and\u0026nbsp;Humility\u003C/h2\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThis month, I\u0026#8217;m meeting with my mom for the first time in over six years. Rather than writing my usual retrospective, this post serves as preparation.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Chr class=\u0022wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity\u0022 /\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIt\u0026#8217;s February 2019, and I\u0026#8217;m riding my bike around Doctor\u0026#8217;s Lake near Jacksonville, Florida. Life had been increasingly difficult and it finally hits me: my emotional demands are exceeding my capacity. I\u2019m anxious about our upcoming move and inability to find a house. My sister and I have been unraveling decades of family lies. I had no idea that I was three months from a mental breakdown, but knew something had to give. As I pedal along, I suddenly realize the podcast in my ears is discussing parental estrangement. I stop, am nearly overcome with a sense of peace, and make my decision.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMy mom was refusing to listen to our concerns. She wouldn\u0026#8217;t meet our need for more truth and less criticism. So I chose estrangement through an ultimatum: get professional help before we talk again. It remains the last time we spoke and since then, I\u0026#8217;ve relied on that boundary as an unsuccessful forcing function. I wanted her to prioritize relationships with her children and grandchildren over her fear of the truth. Nothing since then has changed\u2014only more pain inflicted and more joys unshared.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn late 2023, I considered how to reconnect with my mom. My\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://fs.blog/decision-journal/\u0022\u003Edecision journal\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;showed I was nearing the five-year mark of our estrangement. Three separate therapists had pointed out that completely cutting her from my life was not a healthy boundary. That New Year\u0026#8217;s, inspired by a meaningful quote, I wrote her a letter.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cblockquote class=\u0022wp-block-quote is-layout-flow wp-block-quote-is-layout-flow\u0022\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe day a child realizes that all adults are imperfect, he becomes an adolescent; the day he forgives them, he becomes an adult; the day he forgives himself, he becomes wise. \u003Cbr /\u003E-Alden Nowlan\u003C/p\u003E\u003C/blockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI neither expected nor experienced a miracle.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhile some of our letters since then explored the past, most stayed focused on the present. A few exchanges reached emotional depth, but the majority remained superficial. Once or twice, we approached a breakthrough on a long-standing issue. After I\u0026#8217;d lean into it in my letter, she would change the topic in hers. I had hoped for a non-confrontational process to unpack the past. Instead, it became the avoidance of difficult truths. Our letter writing ultimately deteriorated into her defensive deflections of my uncomfortable questions.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMeanwhile, boxes of childhood memories, career mementos, and marriage keepsakes were returned to me\u2014photos, memorabilia, and clothing. Our family members I had reconnected with became targets of her social media attacks. My sister faced workplace discipline because of our mom. Eventually, she cut ties as well.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAs my therapists had predicted, the situation remained deeply unhealthy.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETrue to form, I sought to better understand the underlying dynamics. \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.artofmanliness.com/people/family/podcast-1039-whats-behind-the-rise-of-parent-child-estrangement/\u0022\u003EBret McKay\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0provided insights on healing from estrangement, while\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.melrobbins.com/episode/episode-289/\u0022\u003EMel Robbins\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0offered strategies for dealing with emotionally immature parents. I learned how to\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/11/well/mind/narcissism-age-empathy.html?campaign_id=9\u0026amp;emc=edit_nn_20240712\u0026amp;instance_id=128581\u0026amp;nl=the-morning%C2%AEi_id=98392334\u0026amp;segment_id=171964\u0026amp;te=1\u0026amp;user_id=9e761973a6cba9d50fb84e5eef9e26c8\u0022\u003Emore effectively handle narcissistic behaviors\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0in both personal and professional contexts rather than avoiding them. I knew my sister needs to be there for any intervention to show a unified front. We would also benefit from a professional mediator\u2014either a therapist or clergy member.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat finally led me to reconnect with my mom now?\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETo be honest, I\u0026#8217;m not sure yet. Over the past six years, my wife and I have experienced several major life events. Some were joyful, others were painful. She should have been part of them. She\u0026#8217;s missed watching our four kids grow, achieve in/out of school, leave for college, and get engaged. Over the decades, I\u0026#8217;ve seen her friends, siblings, son, and now daughter distance themselves. What is next?\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI perceive her mental health declining while my capacity to help increasing. Perhaps the plot of these trend lines have intersected.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat do I hope to achieve?\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhile I\u0026#8217;m maintaining low expectations, I do have specific goals:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Col class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003EMy short-term goal is to simply talk again, with the hope this process leads to forgiveness\u2014\u003Ca href=\u0022https://hbr.org/2023/03/forgiving-a-difficult-colleague\u0022\u003Ea choice I fully control\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EMy medium-term goal is for each party to take ownership of their contribution to our dynamic. This is a choice I only partly control.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EMy long-term goal is to form a new relationship with healthier dynamics than before\u2014a choice I do not control.\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ol\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI asked AI for advice when preparing for this post. The words \u0026#8220;patience\u0026#8221; and \u0026#8220;humility\u0026#8221; were in two of the bullet points. These could have been pulled from my context knowledge. Or, they could be \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.bible.com/bible/59/EPH.4.2\u0022\u003Edivine guidance\u003C/a\u003E. Regardless, they have resonated with me for some time. They are both the title of this blog and a tattoo I\u2019ve been slowly designing. This reconciliation journey will undoubtedly test both and I\u2019m sure all three of us will stumble along the way.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/estrangement/\u0022\u003E#estrangement\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/humility/\u0022\u003E#humility\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/patience/\u0022\u003E#patience\u003C/a\u003E\u003C/p\u003E","context":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1642/context","contentMap":{"en":"\u003Ch2\u003EReconnecting After Estrangement: A Journey of Patience and\u0026nbsp;Humility\u003C/h2\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThis month, I\u0026#8217;m meeting with my mom for the first time in over six years. Or, they could be \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.bible.com/bible/59/EPH.4.2\u0022\u003Edivine guidance\u003C/a\u003E. Regardless, they have resonated with me for some time. They are both the title of this blog and a tattoo I\u2019ve been slowly designing. This reconciliation journey will undoubtedly test both and I\u2019m sure all three of us will stumble along the way.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022http://patlineberry.com/tag/estrangement/\u0022\u003E#estrangement\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022http://patlineberry.com/tag/humility/\u0022\u003E#humility\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022http://patlineberry.com/tag/patience/\u0022\u003E#patience\u003C/a\u003E\u003C/p\u003E","context":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1642/context","contentMap":{"en":"\u003Ch2\u003EReconnecting After Estrangement: A Journey of Patience and Humility\u003C/h2\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThis month, I\u0026#8217;m meeting with my mom for the first time in over six years. Rather than writing my usual retrospective, this post serves as preparation.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Chr class=\u0022wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity\u0022 /\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIt\u0026#8217;s February 2019, and I\u0026#8217;m riding my bike around Doctor\u0026#8217;s Lake near Jacksonville, Florida. Life had been increasingly difficult and it finally hits me: my emotional demands are exceeding my capacity. I\u2019m anxious about our upcoming move and inability to find a house. My sister and I have been unraveling decades of family lies. I had no idea that I was three months from a mental breakdown, but knew something had to give. As I pedal along, I suddenly realize the podcast in my ears is discussing parental estrangement. I stop, am nearly overcome with a sense of peace, and make my decision.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMy mom was refusing to listen to our concerns. She wouldn\u0026#8217;t meet our need for more truth and less gossip. So I chose estrangement through an ultimatum: get professional help before we talk again. It remains the last time we spoke and since then, I\u0026#8217;ve relied on that boundary as an unsuccessful forcing function. I wanted her to prioritize relationships with her children and grandchildren over her fear of the truth. Nothing since then has changed\u2014only more pain inflicted and more joys unshared.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn late 2023, I considered how to reconnect with my mom. My\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://fs.blog/decision-journal/\u0022\u003Edecision journal\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;showed I was nearing the five-year mark of our estrangement. Three separate therapists had pointed out that completely cutting her from my life was not a healthy boundary. That New Year\u0026#8217;s, inspired by a meaningful quote, I wrote her a letter.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cblockquote class=\u0022wp-block-quote is-layout-flow wp-block-quote-is-layout-flow\u0022\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe day a child realizes that all adults are imperfect, he becomes an adolescent; the day he forgives them, he becomes an adult; the day he forgives himself, he becomes wise. \u003Cbr /\u003E-Alden Nowlan\u003C/p\u003E\u003C/blockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI neither expected nor experienced a miracle.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhile some of our letters since then explored the past, most stayed focused on the present. A few exchanges reached emotional depth, but the majority remained superficial. Once or twice, we approached a breakthrough on a long-standing issue. After I\u0026#8217;d lean into it in my letter, she would change the topic in hers. I had hoped for a non-confrontational process to unpack the past. Instead, it became the avoidance of difficult truths. Our letter writing ultimately deteriorated into her defensive deflections of my uncomfortable questions.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMeanwhile, boxes of childhood memories, career mementos, and marriage keepsakes were returned to me\u2014photos, memorabilia, and clothing. Our family members I had reconnected with became targets of her social media attacks. My sister faced workplace discipline because of our mom. Eventually, she cut ties as well.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAs my therapists had predicted, the situation remained deeply unhealthy.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETrue to form, I sought to better understand the underlying dynamics. \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.artofmanliness.com/people/family/podcast-1039-whats-behind-the-rise-of-parent-child-estrangement/\u0022\u003EBret McKay\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;provided insights on healing from estrangement, while\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.melrobbins.com/episode/episode-289/\u0022\u003EMel Robbins\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;offered strategies for dealing with emotionally immature parents. I learned how to\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/11/well/mind/narcissism-age-empathy.html?campaign_id=9\u0026amp;emc=edit_nn_20240712\u0026amp;instance_id=128581\u0026amp;nl=the-morning%C2%AEi_id=98392334\u0026amp;segment_id=171964\u0026amp;te=1\u0026amp;user_id=9e761973a6cba9d50fb84e5eef9e26c8\u0022\u003Emore effectively handle narcissistic behaviors\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;in both personal and professional contexts rather than avoiding them. I knew my sister needs to be there for any intervention to show a unified front. We would also benefit from a professional mediator\u2014either a therapist or clergy member.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat finally led me to reconnect with my mom now?\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETo be honest, I\u0026#8217;m not sure yet. Over the past six years, my wife and I have experienced several major life events. Some were joyful, others were painful. She should have been part of them. She\u0026#8217;s missed watching our four kids grow, achieve in/out of school, leave for college, and get engaged. Over the decades, I\u0026#8217;ve seen her friends, siblings, son, and now daughter distance themselves. What is next?\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI perceive her mental health declining while my capacity to help increasing. Perhaps the plot of these trend lines have intersected.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat do I hope to achieve?\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhile I\u0026#8217;m maintaining low expectations, I do have specific goals:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Col class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003EMy short-term goal is to simply talk again, with the hope this process leads to forgiveness\u2014\u003Ca href=\u0022https://hbr.org/2023/03/forgiving-a-difficult-colleague\u0022\u003Ea choice I fully control\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EMy medium-term goal is for each party to take ownership of their contribution to our dynamic. This is a choice I only partly control.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EMy long-term goal is to form a new relationship with healthier dynamics than before\u2014a choice I do not control.\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ol\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI asked AI for advice when preparing for this post. The words \u0026#8220;patience\u0026#8221; and \u0026#8220;humility\u0026#8221; were in two of the bullet points. These could have been pulled from my context knowledge. Or, they could be \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.bible.com/bible/59/EPH.4.2\u0022\u003Edivine guidance\u003C/a\u003E. Regardless, they have resonated with me for some time. They are both the title of this blog and a tattoo I\u2019ve been slowly designing. This reconciliation journey will undoubtedly test both and I\u2019m sure all three of us will stumble along the way.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022http://patlineberry.com/tag/estrangement/\u0022\u003E#estrangement\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022http://patlineberry.com/tag/humility/\u0022\u003E#humility\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022http://patlineberry.com/tag/patience/\u0022\u003E#patience\u003C/a\u003E\u003C/p\u003E"},"icon":{"type":"Image","url":"https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/image-1.png?w=150","mediaType":"image/png"},"image":{"type":"Image","url":"https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/image-1.png?w=1024","mediaType":"image/png"},"published":"2025-07-16T16:57:56Z","tag":[{"type":"Hashtag","href":"http://patlineberry.com/tag/estrangement/","name":"#estrangement"},{"type":"Hashtag","href":"http://patlineberry.com/tag/humility/","name":"#humility"},{"type":"Hashtag","href":"http://patlineberry.com/tag/patience/","name":"#patience"}],"updated":"2025-07-17T11:38:24Z","url":"http://patlineberry.com/2025/07/16/reconnecting-after-estrangement-a-journey-of-patience-and-humility/","to":["https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"],"cc":["https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/actors/0/followers"],"mediaType":"text/html","replies":{"id":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1642/replies","type":"Collection","first":{"id":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1642/replies?page=1","type":"CollectionPage","partOf":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1642/replies","items":[]}},"likes":{"id":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1642/likes","type":"Collection","totalItems":0},"shares":{"id":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1642/shares","type":"Collection","totalItems":0}},"actor":"http://patlineberry.com/?author=0"}

item.title: [Create] AI Insights: Balancing Benefits and ConcernsArtificial…
item.content:encoded: {"@context":["https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams",{"Hashtag":"as:Hashtag","sensitive":"as:sensitive","dcterms":"http://purl.org/dc/terms/"}],"id":"https://patlineberry.com/?post_type=ap_outbox\u0026p=1678","type":"Create","published":"2025-09-30T13:06:54Z","to":["https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"],"cc":["https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/actors/0/followers"],"object":{"id":"https://patlineberry.com/?p=1656","type":"Note","attachment":[{"type":"Image","url":"https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/create-a-highly-detailed-high-resolution-featured-image-representing-the-theme.png?w=1024","mediaType":"image/png"},{"type":"Image","url":"https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20.37.17.png?w=1024","mediaType":"image/png"}],"attributedTo":"https://patlineberry.com/?author=0","content":"\u003Ch2\u003EAI Insights: Balancing Benefits and\u0026nbsp;Concerns\u003C/h2\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EArtificial intelligence (AI) and large language models (LLMs) have become an integral part of my day since the spring. I\u0026#8217;ve consumed dozens of videos. I have spent hours listening to podcasts. I experienced both disappointments and surprises. I completed courses. I even reinstated my LLC as AI-centric. As these tools\u2014along with their capabilities and user interfaces\u2014continuously evolve, my thinking has evolved alongside them.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMy family, friends, and coworkers have increasingly asked for advice on AI. My wife has lovingly called me iPat for at least ten years, but only recently did I accept the title. My former executive director roasted me this summer as both a management wonk and PatGPT. Nonetheless, this isn\u0026#8217;t a technical review. Instead, I\u0026#8217;m sharing my personal journey with AI while offering guidance for my kids.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003EAvoid the hype\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFinding nuanced perspectives on artificial intelligence is hard.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETechnologists would have you believe it\u0026#8217;s only rational to invest \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.nytimes.com/2025/09/22/technology/nvidia-openai-100-billion-investment.html\u0022\u003Ehundreds of billions of dollars\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0in data centers. Meanwhile, there are \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.nytimes.com/2025/08/08/technology/ai-chatbots-delusions-chatgpt.html?unlocked_article_code=1.dE8.3yoc.7P5JHIYe9vnQ\u0026amp;smid=url-share\u0022\u003Edocumented effects on individuals\u003C/a\u003E and\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.congress.gov/crs-product/R48646\u0022\u003Egrowing impacts on the environment\u003C/a\u003E. Furthermore, the introduction of the efficient \u003Ca href=\u0022https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeepSeek_(chatbot)\u0022\u003EDeepSeek\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0and incremental \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.newyorker.com/culture/open-questions/what-if-ai-doesnt-get-much-better-than-this\u0022\u003EChatGPT-5\u003C/a\u003E upended many earlier assumptions. We are learning in real time how to coexist with rapidly evolving technology.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI\u0026#8217;ve personally found\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.oneusefulthing.org/\u0022\u003EProfessor Ethan Mollick\u0026#8217;s blog\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0offers the most balanced perspective on AI. As my therapist says, a healthy person can hold two contradictory feelings at the same time. AI can be both scary and useful. It can be used to spread misinformation at scale and point doctors to anomalies in medical images. I\u0026#8217;m unsure if \u003Ca href=\u0022https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superintelligence#Challenges_and_uncertainties\u0022\u003ESkynet\u003C/a\u003E will become self-aware. Still, I want humans in the United States to keep an AI competitive advantage.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003EFrom AI Novice to Fractional AI-BizOps Consultant\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI upgraded my cell phone over the winter for two reasons. First, it was an iPhone 12. Second, I wanted Apple Intelligence. I was sold on the promise of cross-app context and a more agentic Siri. I eagerly enabled ChatGPT and surprised, found I already had an account.\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hz6oys4Eem4\u0022\u003EDespite its failings\u003C/a\u003E, I had officially become an AI novice.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EYou know that phenomenon where after learning something new, you start noticing it everywhere? I quickly began spotting Gemini results in my Google searches. Gradually, \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.nngroup.com/articles/ai-changing-search-behaviors/\u0022\u003Emy search behavior evolved\u003C/a\u003E as I shifted cognitive load to the model. My reading and listening habits remained the same. Yet, they naturally began featuring more AI-related content and I switched to an AI-embedded podcast player.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAt work, I began experimenting with AI despite the challenges posed by government cybersecurity protocols. I used it increasingly for summarizing lengthy documents and creating crappy first drafts. People much younger than me developed surprisingly good AI tools to draft formatted awards and evaluations. I was asked to give a lunch talk about my personal knowledge management and use of AI. Though I can\u0026#8217;t quantify the time saved, the learning experience proved valuable.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMy understanding of AI and its use increased step-wise through two courses. Together, they revealed the power of strategically managed context knowledge: \u003Ca href=\u0022https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLVNXAaej57W4d8Sig7khR_XJkcJghYhdk\u0026amp;si=68CRwaN3ZLd_o52s\u0022\u003ETiago Forte\u0026#8217;s Second Brain Enterprise\u003C/a\u003E and \u003Ca href=\u0022https://anthropic.skilljar.com/ai-fluency-framework-foundations\u0022\u003EAnthropic\u0026#8217;s AI-Fluency\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cfigure class=\u0022wp-block-image aligncenter size-large is-style-rectangular\u0022\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\u00221671\u0022 data-permalink=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/2025/09/30/ai-insights-balancing-benefits-and-concerns/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20-37-17/\u0022 data-orig-file=\u0022https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20.37.17.png\u0022 data-orig-size=\u00221650,938\u0022 data-comments-opened=\u00221\u0022 data-image-meta=\u0022{\u0026quot;aperture\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;credit\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;camera\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;caption\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;created_timestamp\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;copyright\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;focal_length\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;iso\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;shutter_speed\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;title\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;orientation\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;}\u0022 data-image-title=\u0022Screenshot 2025-09-28 at 20.37.17\u0022 data-image-description=\u0022\u0022 data-image-caption=\u0022\u0022 data-medium-file=\u0022https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20.37.17.png?w=300\u0022 data-large-file=\u0022https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20.37.17.png?w=1024\u0022 loading=\u0022lazy\u0022 width=\u00221024\u0022 height=\u0022582\u0022 src=\u0022https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20.37.17.png?w=1024\u0022 alt=\u0022\u0022 class=\u0022wp-image-1671\u0022 /\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\u0022wp-element-caption\u0022\u003EContext specificity in large language models\u003C/figcaption\u003E\u003C/figure\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOh, I should mention that I retired in June and began\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.nytimes.com/2025/09/15/business/long-term-unemployment-college-grads.html\u0022\u003Ejob hunting\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;in July. Super good timing, but three months of terminal leave provided \u003Cem\u003Eplenty\u003C/em\u003E of time for learning something new. I planned only a JavaScript course to improve my use of Notion. But, I ended up taking a three month technology sabbatical.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI created a personal strategic context and master prompt through CustomGPTs. I added them to Claude, along with my master resume and various career goals. Over 41 applications, I refined my approach\u2014adjusting at least one level of context. I also learned to leverage Claude for deep company research. For interview preparation, five minutes of AI tokens synthesized information from hundreds of websites and provided interesting questions to consider. Creating a tailored resume and cover letter took 90 minutes in April. Now, it takes just 30 and is a \u003Cem\u003Emuch\u003C/em\u003E better product.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI\u0026#8217;d love to tell you that AI crafted the perfect application, which then led to the perfect job offer. As I mentioned earlier, we should avoid the hype.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAI came up in roughly 75% of my job interviews. Those that know me also know that workflow came up in 100% of my interviews. My job search taught me to reframe this passion as \u0026#8220;business operations improvement.\u0026#8221; Inject some technology, and you have the emerging field of\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.theaiexchange.com/\u0022\u003EAI-operations\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EUltimately, one company offered me 1099 work modernizing their internal operations, including the integration of AI. So yes, artificial intelligence did help me land a job\u2014just not in the way I had expected.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003EAdvice to my kids\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOkay, enough about me. What about you?\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHere are three tips that I think stand the test of time:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Col class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003ERemember that technology companies probably don\u0026#8217;t have your best interests in mind. I agree with Eli Goldratt that the goal of every business is to be profitable now and into the future. And I don\u0026#8217;t fault them for that, but I do hope their algorithms include\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://digitalethics.georgetown.edu/\u0022\u003Enoble purposes\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EPersonal fit matters more than\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://artificialanalysis.ai/models\u0022\u003Eperformance metrics\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0for the vast majority of users. Some focus on the user interface like my wife. Some on integration with Google or Microsoft like my friends. Some prefer voice interaction like my daughter. Coding capabilities are important to my son and context knowledge management to me. Each model\u0026#8217;s tuning and user experience is unique, so experiment. I was a Claude fan, but now prefer ChatGPT and NotebookLM.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003ELastly, embrace the journey! No single prediction about AI\u0026#8217;s future is accurate, though collectively they are useful. Automation will displace some work while creating new opportunities. Still, you can learn to partner with AI as a co-intelligence today. Just don\u0026#8217;t outsource all your critical thinking.\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ol\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/artificial-intelligence/\u0022\u003E#artificialIntelligence\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/large-language-models/\u0022\u003E#largeLanguageModels\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/wfld/\u0022\u003E#WFLD\u003C/a\u003E\u003C/p\u003E","context":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1656/context","contentMap":{"en":"\u003Ch2\u003EAI Insights: Balancing Benefits and\u0026nbsp;Concerns\u003C/h2\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EArtificial intelligence (AI) and large language models (LLMs) have become an integral part of my day since the spring. I\u0026#8217;ve consumed dozens of videos. I have spent hours listening to podcasts. I experienced both disappointments and surprises. I completed courses. I even reinstated my LLC as AI-centric. As these tools\u2014along with their capabilities and user interfaces\u2014continuously evolve, my thinking has evolved alongside them.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMy family, friends, and coworkers have increasingly asked for advice on AI. My wife has lovingly called me iPat for at least ten years, but only recently did I accept the title. My former executive director roasted me this summer as both a management wonk and PatGPT. Nonetheless, this isn\u0026#8217;t a technical review. Instead, I\u0026#8217;m sharing my personal journey with AI while offering guidance for my kids.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003EAvoid the hype\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFinding nuanced perspectives on artificial intelligence is hard.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETechnologists would have you believe it\u0026#8217;s only rational to invest \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.nytimes.com/2025/09/22/technology/nvidia-openai-100-billion-investment.html\u0022\u003Ehundreds of billions of dollars\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0in data centers. Meanwhile, there are \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.nytimes.com/2025/08/08/technology/ai-chatbots-delusions-chatgpt.html?unlocked_article_code=1.dE8.3yoc.7P5JHIYe9vnQ\u0026amp;smid=url-share\u0022\u003Edocumented effects on individuals\u003C/a\u003E and\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.congress.gov/crs-product/R48646\u0022\u003Egrowing impacts on the environment\u003C/a\u003E. Furthermore, the introduction of the efficient \u003Ca href=\u0022https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeepSeek_(chatbot)\u0022\u003EDeepSeek\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0and incremental \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.newyorker.com/culture/open-questions/what-if-ai-doesnt-get-much-better-than-this\u0022\u003EChatGPT-5\u003C/a\u003E upended many earlier assumptions. We are learning in real time how to coexist with rapidly evolving technology.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI\u0026#8217;ve personally found\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.oneusefulthing.org/\u0022\u003EProfessor Ethan Mollick\u0026#8217;s blog\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0offers the most balanced perspective on AI. As my therapist says, a healthy person can hold two contradictory feelings at the same time. AI can be both scary and useful. It can be used to spread misinformation at scale and point doctors to anomalies in medical images. I\u0026#8217;m unsure if \u003Ca href=\u0022https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superintelligence#Challenges_and_uncertainties\u0022\u003ESkynet\u003C/a\u003E will become self-aware. Still, I want humans in the United States to keep an AI competitive advantage.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003EFrom AI Novice to Fractional AI-BizOps Consultant\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI upgraded my cell phone over the winter for two reasons. First, it was an iPhone 12. Second, I wanted Apple Intelligence. I was sold on the promise of cross-app context and a more agentic Siri. I eagerly enabled ChatGPT and surprised, found I already had an account.\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hz6oys4Eem4\u0022\u003EDespite its failings\u003C/a\u003E, I had officially become an AI novice.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EYou know that phenomenon where after learning something new, you start noticing it everywhere? I quickly began spotting Gemini results in my Google searches. Gradually, \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.nngroup.com/articles/ai-changing-search-behaviors/\u0022\u003Emy search behavior evolved\u003C/a\u003E as I shifted cognitive load to the model. My reading and listening habits remained the same. Yet, they naturally began featuring more AI-related content and I switched to an AI-embedded podcast player.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAt work, I began experimenting with AI despite the challenges posed by government cybersecurity protocols. I used it increasingly for summarizing lengthy documents and creating crappy first drafts. People much younger than me developed surprisingly good AI tools to draft formatted awards and evaluations. I was asked to give a lunch talk about my personal knowledge management and use of AI. Though I can\u0026#8217;t quantify the time saved, the learning experience proved valuable.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMy understanding of AI and its use increased step-wise through two courses. Together, they revealed the power of strategically managed context knowledge: \u003Ca href=\u0022https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLVNXAaej57W4d8Sig7khR_XJkcJghYhdk\u0026amp;si=68CRwaN3ZLd_o52s\u0022\u003ETiago Forte\u0026#8217;s Second Brain Enterprise\u003C/a\u003E and \u003Ca href=\u0022https://anthropic.skilljar.com/ai-fluency-framework-foundations\u0022\u003EAnthropic\u0026#8217;s AI-Fluency\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cfigure class=\u0022wp-block-image aligncenter size-large is-style-rectangular\u0022\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\u00221671\u0022 data-permalink=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/2025/09/30/ai-insights-balancing-benefits-and-concerns/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20-37-17/\u0022 data-orig-file=\u0022https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20.37.17.png\u0022 data-orig-size=\u00221650,938\u0022 data-comments-opened=\u00221\u0022 data-image-meta=\u0022{\u0026quot;aperture\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;credit\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;camera\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;caption\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;created_timestamp\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;copyright\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;focal_length\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;iso\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;shutter_speed\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;title\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;orientation\u0026quot;:\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;}\u0022 data-image-title=\u0022Screenshot 2025-09-28 at 20.37.17\u0022 data-image-description=\u0022\u0022 data-image-caption=\u0022\u0022 data-medium-file=\u0022https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20.37.17.png?w=300\u0022 data-large-file=\u0022https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20.37.17.png?w=1024\u0022 loading=\u0022lazy\u0022 width=\u00221024\u0022 height=\u0022582\u0022 src=\u0022https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/screenshot-2025-09-28-at-20.37.17.png?w=1024\u0022 alt=\u0022\u0022 class=\u0022wp-image-1671\u0022 /\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\u0022wp-element-caption\u0022\u003EContext specificity in large language models\u003C/figcaption\u003E\u003C/figure\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOh, I should mention that I retired in June and began\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.nytimes.com/2025/09/15/business/long-term-unemployment-college-grads.html\u0022\u003Ejob hunting\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;in July. Super good timing, but three months of terminal leave provided \u003Cem\u003Eplenty\u003C/em\u003E of time for learning something new. I planned only a JavaScript course to improve my use of Notion. But, I ended up taking a three month technology sabbatical.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI created a personal strategic context and master prompt through CustomGPTs. I added them to Claude, along with my master resume and various career goals. Over 41 applications, I refined my approach\u2014adjusting at least one level of context. I also learned to leverage Claude for deep company research. For interview preparation, five minutes of AI tokens synthesized information from hundreds of websites and provided interesting questions to consider. Creating a tailored resume and cover letter took 90 minutes in April. Now, it takes just 30 and is a \u003Cem\u003Emuch\u003C/em\u003E better product.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI\u0026#8217;d love to tell you that AI crafted the perfect application, which then led to the perfect job offer. As I mentioned earlier, we should avoid the hype.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAI came up in roughly 75% of my job interviews. Those that know me also know that workflow came up in 100% of my interviews. My job search taught me to reframe this passion as \u0026#8220;business operations improvement.\u0026#8221; Inject some technology, and you have the emerging field of\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.theaiexchange.com/\u0022\u003EAI-operations\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EUltimately, one company offered me 1099 work modernizing their internal operations, including the integration of AI. So yes, artificial intelligence did help me land a job\u2014just not in the way I had expected.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003EAdvice to my kids\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOkay, enough about me. What about you?\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHere are three tips that I think stand the test of time:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Col class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003ERemember that technology companies probably don\u0026#8217;t have your best interests in mind. I agree with Eli Goldratt that the goal of every business is to be profitable now and into the future. And I don\u0026#8217;t fault them for that, but I do hope their algorithms include\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://digitalethics.georgetown.edu/\u0022\u003Enoble purposes\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EPersonal fit matters more than\u00a0\u003Ca href=\u0022https://artificialanalysis.ai/models\u0022\u003Eperformance metrics\u003C/a\u003E\u00a0for the vast majority of users. Some focus on the user interface like my wife. Some on integration with Google or Microsoft like my friends. Some prefer voice interaction like my daughter. Coding capabilities are important to my son and context knowledge management to me. Each model\u0026#8217;s tuning and user experience is unique, so experiment. I was a Claude fan, but now prefer ChatGPT and NotebookLM.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003ELastly, embrace the journey! No single prediction about AI\u0026#8217;s future is accurate, though collectively they are useful. Automation will displace some work while creating new opportunities. Still, you can learn to partner with AI as a co-intelligence today. Just don\u0026#8217;t outsource all your critical thinking.\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ol\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/artificial-intelligence/\u0022\u003E#artificialIntelligence\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/large-language-models/\u0022\u003E#largeLanguageModels\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 item.title: [Create] Coast Guard Retirement: Essential Resources…
item.content:encoded: {"@context":["https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams",{"Hashtag":"as:Hashtag","sensitive":"as:sensitive","dcterms":"http://purl.org/dc/terms/","gts":"https://gotosocial.org/ns#","interactionPolicy":{"@id":"gts:interactionPolicy","@type":"@id"},"canQuote":{"@id":"gts:canQuote","@type":"@id"},"canReply":{"@id":"gts:canReply","@type":"@id"},"canLike":{"@id":"gts:canLike","@type":"@id"},"canAnnounce":{"@id":"gts:canAnnounce","@type":"@id"},"automaticApproval":{"@id":"gts:automaticApproval","@type":"@id"},"manualApproval":{"@id":"gts:manualApproval","@type":"@id"},"always":{"@id":"gts:always","@type":"@id"}}],"id":"https://patlineberry.com/?post_type=ap_outbox\u0026p=1686","type":"Create","published":"2025-11-29T20:08:25Z","to":["https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"],"cc":["https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/actors/0/followers"],"interactionPolicy":{"canAnnounce":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public","always":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"},"canLike":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public","always":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"},"canQuote":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public","always":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"},"canReply":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public","always":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"}},"object":{"id":"https://patlineberry.com/?p=1679","type":"Note","attachment":[{"type":"Image","url":"https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/image.png?w=1024","mediaType":"image/png"}],"attributedTo":"https://patlineberry.com/?author=0","content":"\u003Ch2\u003ECoast Guard Retirement: Essential Resources and\u0026nbsp;Timeline\u003C/h2\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThis month\u0026#8217;s unsolicited opinion on workflow improvement focuses on a major project I just completed: my retirement from active duty.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI used many resources (and \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.notion.com/\u0022\u003ENotion\u003C/a\u003E!) for my year long integrated master schedule. And, I found Patrick Kulakowski\u0026#8217;s \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.navyretirementguide.com/\u0022\u003ENavy Retirement \u0026amp; Separation Resource Guide\u003C/a\u003E to be the most useful.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI\u0026#8217;ve shared his guide with at least a dozen people since coming across it. But, I always have to mention that they will need to translate from Navy to Coast Guard. So, I reached out to Patrick and offered my help with a Coast Guard\u2013specific appendix. Below is my draft and I welcome your feedback in the comments.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPatrick provides this great resource guide for free and I won\u0026#8217;t be updating this blog post with our edits. Please visit his website for the latest version and while you\u0026#8217;re there, consider a donation!\u003C/p\u003E\u003Chr class=\u0022wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity\u0022 /\u003E\u003Ch2 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESection 2 \u2013 Retirement Planning Timeline\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/h2\u003E\u003Cfigure class=\u0022wp-block-table\u0022\u003E\u003Ctable class=\u0022has-fixed-layout\u0022\u003E\u003Ctbody\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENavy reference\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ECoast Guard equivalent\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENotes\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ESubmit retirement request in NSIPS\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ESubmit request memo to PSC (Officers: OPM-1; Enlisted: EPM-1; Reserve: RPM-1)\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EProcess is managed by \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.dcms.uscg.mil/Our-Organization/Assistant-Commandant-for-Human-Resources-CG-1/Personnel-Service-Center-PSC/\u0022\u003EPSC\u003C/a\u003E (CAC required for templates)\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EUse NPPSC checklists/forms\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EUse SPO \u0026amp; PSC process guides/checklists\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EVerify record in NSIPS for DD214\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EVerify a pdf or hard copy draft DD214\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ESPO builds in DA\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EmyPay/DS Logon setup\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Ca href=\u0022https://uscgpublic.b2clogin.com/uscgpublic.onmicrosoft.com/b2c_1a_da_xprod_signup_signin_phoneoremailmfa/oauth2/v2.0/authorize?client_id=8987070a-ef6b-48c9-883a-53295f00c3a2\u0026amp;redirect_uri=https%3A%2F%2Fhcm.direct-access.uscg.mil%2Foauth2%2Fidpresponse\u0026amp;response_type=code\u0026amp;scope=openid%20offline_access%20https%3A%2F%2FUSCGPublic.onmicrosoft.com%2F8987070a-ef6b-48c9-883a-53295f00c3a2%2Ftoken\u0026amp;state=YALb1yAfGRzCh7Pz2HmD4r%2FMGeev2LnKjEnfePvb%2FhEQgYRNPfaz%2Fz7VH6hqz9OWheRJ%2BVhAA26z6MRbIE3pYIbfSNf4VKpjLRJdfWiGqt3Cqk5leN4OaTIrl4zY1vudVjaz0HTud%2FBVn%2FkjvoXAs2QsM2DE58vbvNIksR5pa7oKjGmpWGQU%2BfAcnllx9gLszjkaNuOTUoqZWEukxiBuj8ufDmBaGb8njqkLI38OEy0Gx%2Bgk2cR%2B0shNTwVrnKumoPf2xOJXTxIaiHDYj%2FLsTQZ6jKkT1VY8yhTMg7PRx9qob4m38AmfrlhGEcUpmVA%3D\u0022\u003EDirect Access Self-Service\u003C/a\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ERequest retired login after; \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.dcms.uscg.mil/ppc/ras/\u0022\u003ERAS\u003C/a\u003E has self-service guides\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ERetirement orders, final pay via DFAS\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EFinal pay \u0026amp; accounts via PPC-SEP or PPC-RAS\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EPPC-SEP handles separation pay; PPC-RAS establishes retired pay; SPO finalizes orders\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ENAVADMINs\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.dcms.uscg.mil/General-Messages/\u0022\u003EALCOAST / ACN\u003C/a\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003C/tbody\u003E\u003C/table\u003E\u003C/figure\u003E\u003Ch2 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESection 3 \u2013 Transition Preparations\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/h2\u003E\u003Cfigure class=\u0022wp-block-table\u0022\u003E\u003Ctable class=\u0022has-fixed-layout\u0022\u003E\u003Ctbody\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENavy reference\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ECoast Guard equivalent\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENotes\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ENavy COOL\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.cool.osd.mil/uscg/index.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com\u0022\u003ECoast Guard COOL\u003C/a\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EFunded through Coast Guard appropriation\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EDoD SkillBridge\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EUSCG SkillBridge\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EUSCG mirrors DoDI 1322.29; see ACN 008/22 and \u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.dcms.uscg.mil/Our-Organization/Assistant-Commandant-for-Human-Resources-CG-1/Health-Safety-and-Work-Life-CG-11/Office-of-Work-Life-CG-111/Transition-Assistance-Program/TAP-Skillbridge/\u0022\u003ETAP Skillbridge page\u003C/a\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003C/tbody\u003E\u003C/table\u003E\u003C/figure\u003E\u003Ch2 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESection 4 \u2013 Separation History \u0026amp; But, I always have to mention that they will need to translate from Navy to Coast Guard. So, I reached out to Patrick and offered my help with a Coast Guard\u2013specific appendix. Below is my draft and I welcome your feedback in the comments.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPatrick provides this great resource guide for free and I won\u0026#8217;t be updating this blog post with our edits. retirees request records\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003C/tbody\u003E\u003C/table\u003E\u003C/figure\u003E\u003Ch2 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESection 9 \u2013 Additional Information \u0026amp; Benefits\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/h2\u003E\u003Cfigure class=\u0022wp-block-table\u0022\u003E\u003Ctable class=\u0022has-fixed-layout\u0022\u003E\u003Ctbody\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENavy reference\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ECoast Guard equivalent\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENotes\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ERetirement flag/certificate requests (Navy)\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EUSCG Retirement Certificates via PPC-SEP (unit memo with 60-day lead time)\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EPPC page provides memo \u0026amp; timing; SPO/command submits\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003C/tbody\u003E\u003C/table\u003E\u003C/figure\u003E\u003Ch2 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESection 10 \u2013 Legal Considerations\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/h2\u003E\u003Cfigure class=\u0022wp-block-table\u0022\u003E\u003Ctable class=\u0022has-fixed-layout\u0022\u003E\u003Ctbody\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENavy reference\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ECoast Guard equivalent\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENotes\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EDD-2945 (ethics \u201cletter of opinion\u201d)\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ESame federal form; consult District/Command Legal\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ECoast Guard JAG provides advice; form is DoD-wide.\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EForeign Government Employment approvals\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EUSCG Retiree Services Program (FGE approvals)\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EDHS delegated to USCG; allow ~6 months for approval\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003C/tbody\u003E\u003C/table\u003E\u003C/figure\u003E\u003Ch2 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESection 11 \u2013 Digital Tools \u0026amp; Resources\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/h2\u003E\u003Cfigure reference\u003C/strong\u003E\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ECoast Guard (DA)\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EmyPay (DFAS)\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EDA Retiree Self-Service\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ENavy COOL\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ECG COOL\u003C/td\u003E\u003C/tr\u003E\u003Ctr\u003E\u003Ctd\u003ENAVADMIN\u003C/td\u003E\u003Ctd\u003EALCOAST / item.title: [Create] Balancing Productivity and Family: A…
item.content:encoded: {"@context":["https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams",{"Hashtag":"as:Hashtag","sensitive":"as:sensitive","dcterms":"http://purl.org/dc/terms/","gts":"https://gotosocial.org/ns#","interactionPolicy":{"@id":"gts:interactionPolicy","@type":"@id"},"canQuote":{"@id":"gts:canQuote","@type":"@id"},"canReply":{"@id":"gts:canReply","@type":"@id"},"canLike":{"@id":"gts:canLike","@type":"@id"},"canAnnounce":{"@id":"gts:canAnnounce","@type":"@id"},"automaticApproval":{"@id":"gts:automaticApproval","@type":"@id"},"manualApproval":{"@id":"gts:manualApproval","@type":"@id"},"always":{"@id":"gts:always","@type":"@id"}}],"id":"https://patlineberry.com/?post_type=ap_outbox\u0026p=1697","type":"Create","published":"2026-01-31T15:43:06Z","to":["https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"],"cc":["https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/actors/0/followers"],"interactionPolicy":{"canAnnounce":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public","always":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"},"canLike":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public","always":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"},"canQuote":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public","always":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"},"canReply":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public","always":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"}},"object":{"id":"https://patlineberry.com/?p=1687","type":"Note","attachment":[{"type":"Image","url":"https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image.png?w=1024","mediaType":"image/png"}],"attributedTo":"https://patlineberry.com/?author=0","content":"\u003Ch2\u003EBalancing Productivity and Family: A Dadmin\u0026nbsp;Guide\u003C/h2\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EMy wife and I are standing on the porch in Florida, waiting for the school bus to arrive. The heat is building\u2014both outside our house and inside our bodies. We\u0026#8217;ve received several alerts today from the county school portal about missing assignments. We see school as our kids\u0026#8217; job. We work hard to give a stable, loving environment. In turn, we expect them to work hard to fulfill their age-appropriate responsibilities. Completing class assignments isn\u0026#8217;t just how they learn the material\u2014it\u0026#8217;s how they build work ethic.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EOur second oldest can tell we\u0026#8217;re waiting for him and slows his pace. We launch into our interrogation as he approaches. He\u0026#8217;s only nine and quickly tears up. This isn\u0026#8217;t how we want to parent. We need a new approach.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003EDad + admin = Dadmin\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI\u0026#8217;m an\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.gallup.com/cliftonstrengths/en/252161/arranger-theme.aspx\u0022\u003Earranger\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI make the bed every morning and love a freshly cleaned car. I\u0026#8217;m fascinated by the\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_constraints\u0022\u003ETheory of Constraints\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;and love aligning groups toward a common goal. I\u0026#8217;ve re-engineered physical production control across a 2,000-person industrial facility and knowledge work in the C-suite of a 42,000-person organization.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI\u0026#8217;m also\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.gallup.com/cliftonstrengths/en/252239/focus-theme.aspx\u0022\u003Efocused\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EOver time, I\u0026#8217;ve learned that I\u0026#8217;ll forget something if it isn\u0026#8217;t in my calendar or task manager. I need a system that tells me what to do and when to do it to break my attention. It should also help manage my time holistically across roles. This way, I avoid local optima.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EMy wife and I settled on weekly\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.artofmanliness.com/people/family/creating-a-positive-family-culture-how-to-plan-and-lead-a-weekly-family-meeting/\u0022\u003Efamily meetings\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;as our new approach. The six of us took turns expressing gratitude and provided feedback before diving into the logistics of the upcoming week. Alas, they fizzled out after a few months. My inner nerd began to overwhelm my wife\u2019s free spirit. Two of the kids began to seek the gold star that would come each weekend. The other two began to dread what became known as Dadmin.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI had reduced loving check-ins with each other and gentle nudges of our kids into a production meeting. My well-intentioned questions had again turned into an inquisition. We again needed a new approach.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003EThe system\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003E\u003Ca href=\u0022https://calnewport.com/the-productivity-funnel/\u0022\u003ECal Newport\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;teaches that any good productivity system does three things:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Col class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003EEasily\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Ecaptures\u003C/em\u003E\u0026nbsp;open obligations in a trusted repository\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAllows for\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Econfiguration\u003C/em\u003E\u0026nbsp;by due date, status, context, etc.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHelps you\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Econtrol\u003C/em\u003E\u0026nbsp;time allocated to the top priorities\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ol\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003ESimple in theory, but not always easy in practice.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI\u0026#8217;ve been iterating on\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://patlineberry.notion.site/#84dfaa27fd08480cbf1b4b48e0cf3519\u0022\u003Emy system\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;for about a decade. Some improvements were technology-related, others came from feedback by those it touched. Over time, two principles emerged:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Col class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003EKeep the technology easy for\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Ethe user\u003C/em\u003E\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAllow for\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Eothers\u003C/em\u003E\u0026nbsp;emotional self-pacing\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ol\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EYes, I rediscovered the importance of user experience\u0026#8230;\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003ETiago Forte calls my style \u0026#8220;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://fortelabs.com/blog/the-4-notetaking-styles-how-to-choose-a-digital-notes-app-as-your-second-brain/\u0022\u003Ethe architect\u003C/a\u003E.\u0026#8221; I view the world through systems and enjoy discovering their structure. This shows in my Notion workspace with through APIs, relational database properties, and artificial intelligence. It has become my second brain. \u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EBut this integrated ecosystem of tasks, notes, projects, and areas is WAY too complicated for my family. They don\u0026#8217;t find personal productivity nearly as fun as I do! They prefer Apple\u0026#8217;s simpler suite of calendars, reminders, and notes that can be easily shared.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003ESo, I pull tasks from my various task managers and deliver them to a specific family member through an intuitive app carried in their pocket that includes a reminder:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cul class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003EOur integrated, color-coded Calendar helps us find the best slots for doctor appointments and triage rides when we\u0026#8217;re double-booked.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EThe smart grocery list in Reminders lets everyone add items. It organizes them by aisle and whoever is shopping can simply check them off.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWe use shared Notes for everything from the kids building their Christmas lists to saving ideas for renovating our backyard.\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ul\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EIt took me only a few years to learn this first principle. The second continues to be an area I work on. An obvious extension of focusing on the user experience is to meet others where they\u0026#8217;re at.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EFor example, I learned the hard way that my wife dreads our budget review and my daughter her grade book. What I see as teamwork, they see as me asking difficult questions they aren\u0026#8217;t ready to answer. After some trial and error, I now do the detailed analysis\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Eindependently\u003C/em\u003E and send them the highlights. We then review together when\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Ethey\u0026#8217;re\u003C/em\u003E\u0026nbsp;ready.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EConsidering their user experience balances my need to get things done with my family\u0026#8217;s need to not be micromanaged. Besides the above examples, my wife considers these use cases a success:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cul class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003ECar maintenance on vehicles rarely in our driveway\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003ESchool communications and tutor coordination with slightly less teenage attitude\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EMedical bills for young adults learning to navigate insurance paperwork\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EPreventative house maintenance aligned to our the specific context of our house and location\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ul\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003E\u201cYou\u2019re willing to sacrifice your relationship for his future.\u201d\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EMy wife said this to me a few years back.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EWe were struggling at the time to help our second oldest align his aspirations and effort. She meant it as a compliment, and I took it that way. In fact, he later presented me with the mentor pin at his Eagle Scout Court of Honor. It was his way of appreciating my help in getting him across that particular finish line\u0026#8230;.within days of the age cutoff.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003ELooking back, though, I only had to risk my relationship because I didn\u0026#8217;t recognize his emotions.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI\u2019m used to professional process improvement implementations. I\u2019m versed in breaking down functional stovepipes in the pursuit of an overarching organizational goal. I\u0026#8217;ve been taught to acknowledge, but generally remove emotions from the decision process.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EThis was my mistake: emotions matter, both at home and at work. I didn\u0026#8217;t realize that my big picture could be his small\u2014especially in the moment. I only considered my user administrative experience, not his emotional.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EWhile writing this post, we asked our son for his best and worst Dadmin memories. His answer for both: accountability.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EHe appreciates that my system provided the scaffolding he needed for the professional path he\u0026#8217;s on today. It was also hard facing reality when he struggled to meet expectations, ours or his own. A checklist review in front of his siblings that highlighted those moments made it even harder.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EMy wife and I do hope our kids carry on the Dadmin tradition. I just hope they do so in a more emotionally and user experience attuned way.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/priorities/\u0022\u003E#priorities\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/theory-of-constraints/\u0022\u003E#theoryOfConstraints\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/workflow/\u0022\u003E#workflow\u003C/a\u003E\u003C/p\u003E","context":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1687/context","contentMap":{"en":"\u003Ch2\u003EBalancing Productivity and Family: A Dadmin\u0026nbsp;Guide\u003C/h2\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EMy wife and I are standing on the porch in Florida, waiting for the school bus to arrive. The heat is building\u2014both outside our house and inside our bodies. We\u0026#8217;ve received several alerts today from the county school portal about missing assignments. We see school as our kids\u0026#8217; job. We work hard to give a stable, loving environment. In turn, we expect them to work hard to fulfill their age-appropriate responsibilities. Completing class assignments isn\u0026#8217;t just how they learn the material\u2014it\u0026#8217;s how they build work ethic.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EOur second oldest can tell we\u0026#8217;re waiting for him and slows his pace. We launch into our interrogation as he approaches. He\u0026#8217;s only nine and quickly tears up. This isn\u0026#8217;t how we want to parent. We need a new approach.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003EDad + admin = Dadmin\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI\u0026#8217;m an\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.gallup.com/cliftonstrengths/en/252161/arranger-theme.aspx\u0022\u003Earranger\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI make the bed every morning and love a freshly cleaned car. I\u0026#8217;m fascinated by the\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_constraints\u0022\u003ETheory of Constraints\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;and love aligning groups toward a common goal. I\u0026#8217;ve re-engineered physical production control across a 2,000-person industrial facility and knowledge work in the C-suite of a 42,000-person organization.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI\u0026#8217;m also\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.gallup.com/cliftonstrengths/en/252239/focus-theme.aspx\u0022\u003Efocused\u003C/a\u003E.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EOver time, I\u0026#8217;ve learned that I\u0026#8217;ll forget something if it isn\u0026#8217;t in my calendar or task manager. I need a system that tells me what to do and when to do it to break my attention. It should also help manage my time holistically across roles. This way, I avoid local optima.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EMy wife and I settled on weekly\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://www.artofmanliness.com/people/family/creating-a-positive-family-culture-how-to-plan-and-lead-a-weekly-family-meeting/\u0022\u003Efamily meetings\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;as our new approach. The six of us took turns expressing gratitude and provided feedback before diving into the logistics of the upcoming week. Alas, they fizzled out after a few months. My inner nerd began to overwhelm my wife\u2019s free spirit. Two of the kids began to seek the gold star that would come each weekend. The other two began to dread what became known as Dadmin.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI had reduced loving check-ins with each other and gentle nudges of our kids into a production meeting. My well-intentioned questions had again turned into an inquisition. We again needed a new approach.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003EThe system\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003E\u003Ca href=\u0022https://calnewport.com/the-productivity-funnel/\u0022\u003ECal Newport\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;teaches that any good productivity system does three things:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Col class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003EEasily\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Ecaptures\u003C/em\u003E\u0026nbsp;open obligations in a trusted repository\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAllows for\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Econfiguration\u003C/em\u003E\u0026nbsp;by due date, status, context, etc.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHelps you\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Econtrol\u003C/em\u003E\u0026nbsp;time allocated to the top priorities\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ol\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003ESimple in theory, but not always easy in practice.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI\u0026#8217;ve been iterating on\u0026nbsp;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://patlineberry.notion.site/#84dfaa27fd08480cbf1b4b48e0cf3519\u0022\u003Emy system\u003C/a\u003E\u0026nbsp;for about a decade. Some improvements were technology-related, others came from feedback by those it touched. Over time, two principles emerged:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Col class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003EKeep the technology easy for\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Ethe user\u003C/em\u003E\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAllow for\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Eothers\u003C/em\u003E\u0026nbsp;emotional self-pacing\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ol\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EYes, I rediscovered the importance of user experience\u0026#8230;\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003ETiago Forte calls my style \u0026#8220;\u003Ca href=\u0022https://fortelabs.com/blog/the-4-notetaking-styles-how-to-choose-a-digital-notes-app-as-your-second-brain/\u0022\u003Ethe architect\u003C/a\u003E.\u0026#8221; I view the world through systems and enjoy discovering their structure. This shows in my Notion workspace with through APIs, relational database properties, and artificial intelligence. It has become my second brain. \u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EBut this integrated ecosystem of tasks, notes, projects, and areas is WAY too complicated for my family. They don\u0026#8217;t find personal productivity nearly as fun as I do! They prefer Apple\u0026#8217;s simpler suite of calendars, reminders, and notes that can be easily shared.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003ESo, I pull tasks from my various task managers and deliver them to a specific family member through an intuitive app carried in their pocket that includes a reminder:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cul class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003EOur integrated, color-coded Calendar helps us find the best slots for doctor appointments and triage rides when we\u0026#8217;re double-booked.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EThe smart grocery list in Reminders lets everyone add items. It organizes them by aisle and whoever is shopping can simply check them off.\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWe use shared Notes for everything from the kids building their Christmas lists to saving ideas for renovating our backyard.\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ul\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EIt took me only a few years to learn this first principle. The second continues to be an area I work on. An obvious extension of focusing on the user experience is to meet others where they\u0026#8217;re at.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EFor example, I learned the hard way that my wife dreads our budget review and my daughter her grade book. What I see as teamwork, they see as me asking difficult questions they aren\u0026#8217;t ready to answer. After some trial and error, I now do the detailed analysis\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Eindependently\u003C/em\u003E and send them the highlights. We then review together when\u0026nbsp;\u003Cem\u003Ethey\u0026#8217;re\u003C/em\u003E\u0026nbsp;ready.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EConsidering their user experience balances my need to get things done with my family\u0026#8217;s need to not be micromanaged. Besides the above examples, my wife considers these use cases a success:\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cul class=\u0022wp-block-list\u0022\u003E\u003Cli\u003ECar maintenance on vehicles rarely in our driveway\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003ESchool communications and tutor coordination with slightly less teenage attitude\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EMedical bills for young adults learning to navigate insurance paperwork\u003C/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EPreventative house maintenance aligned to our the specific context of our house and location\u003C/li\u003E\u003C/ul\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\u0022wp-block-heading\u0022\u003E\u201cYou\u2019re willing to sacrifice your relationship for his future.\u201d\u003C/h3\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EMy wife said this to me a few years back.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EWe were struggling at the time to help our second oldest align his aspirations and effort. She meant it as a compliment, and I took it that way. In fact, he later presented me with the mentor pin at his Eagle Scout Court of Honor. It was his way of appreciating my help in getting him across that particular finish line\u0026#8230;.within days of the age cutoff.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003ELooking back, though, I only had to risk my relationship because I didn\u0026#8217;t recognize his emotions.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EI\u2019m used to professional process improvement implementations. I\u2019m versed in breaking down functional stovepipes in the pursuit of an overarching organizational goal. I\u0026#8217;ve been taught to acknowledge, but generally remove emotions from the decision process.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EThis was my mistake: emotions matter, both at home and at work. I didn\u0026#8217;t realize that my big picture could be his small\u2014especially in the moment. I only considered my user administrative experience, not his emotional.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EWhile writing this post, we asked our son for his best and worst Dadmin memories. His answer for both: accountability.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EHe appreciates that my system provided the scaffolding he needed for the professional path he\u0026#8217;s on today. It was also hard facing reality when he struggled to meet expectations, ours or his own. A checklist review in front of his siblings that highlighted those moments made it even harder.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp class=\u0022wp-block-paragraph\u0022\u003EMy wife and I do hope our kids carry on the Dadmin tradition. I just hope they do so in a more emotionally and user experience attuned way.\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/priorities/\u0022\u003E#priorities\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/theory-of-constraints/\u0022\u003E#theoryOfConstraints\u003C/a\u003E \u003Ca rel=\u0022tag\u0022 class=\u0022hashtag u-tag u-category\u0022 href=\u0022https://patlineberry.com/tag/workflow/\u0022\u003E#workflow\u003C/a\u003E\u003C/p\u003E"},"icon":{"type":"Image","url":"https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image.png?w=150","mediaType":"image/png"},"image":{"type":"Image","url":"https://patlineberry.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image.png?w=1024","mediaType":"image/png"},"published":"2026-01-31T15:43:06Z","tag":[{"type":"Hashtag","href":"https://patlineberry.com/tag/priorities/","name":"#priorities"},{"type":"Hashtag","href":"https://patlineberry.com/tag/theory-of-constraints/","name":"#theoryOfConstraints"},{"type":"Hashtag","href":"https://patlineberry.com/tag/workflow/","name":"#workflow"}],"url":"https://patlineberry.com/2026/01/31/balancing-productivity-and-family-a-dadmin-guide/","to":["https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"],"cc":["https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/actors/0/followers"],"mediaType":"text/html","replies":{"id":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1687/replies","type":"Collection","first":{"id":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1687/replies?page=1","type":"CollectionPage","partOf":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1687/replies","items":[]}},"likes":{"id":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1687/likes","type":"Collection","totalItems":0},"shares":{"id":"https://public-api.wordpress.com/wpcom/activitypub-1.0/sites/176659839/posts/1687/shares","type":"Collection","totalItems":0},"interactionPolicy":{"canAnnounce":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public","always":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"},"canLike":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public","always":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"},"canQuote":{"automaticApproval":"https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Pu item.title: The Benefits of Blogging Over Social Media
item.dc:creator: patlineberry
item.content:encoded:
"Why start a blog?", you ask. "Wouldn't Facebook/Twitter/Instagram be easier?", you continue.

First, I think I've been searching some time for a creative outlet. My hobbies have included, in chronological order: guitar, kayaking, beer brewing, cycling, winemaking, soda making, tattoos, motorcycles, triathlons, poetry, banjo, fountain pens, calligraphy, and now maybe a blog. Maybe this is another flash in the pan or maybe it'll stick and grow into something more.

Secondly, Cal Newport told me to. As I'll reveal over time I went though a bit of a personal crisis the past year and reflected quite a bit on my values, skills, and priorities in life. I'm not big on the "socials", but do to think I have something to offer those willing to read. Maybe this will help me understand who I am as a husband/father/brother/friend/leader/employee or maybe it turn into a distraction that I need to separate myself from.

Deb gave me that title by the way. That's us on a COVID-19 date to Walmart. You can't tell, but we're smiling. I love her more than anything in the world and wouldn't be alive today without her.
